questions.text: The instrument given in image is used to measure :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proptosis The given image is of the procedure done for measuring proptosis using HERTEL’S EXOPHTHALMOMETER.

Highyeild:

EXOPHTHALMOMETRY lt evaluates the degree of forward displacement of the globe. It measures the forward distance between the lateral orbital rim and apex of cornea, with the eye looking straight ahead. Normal values vary between 10 and 21 mm and are symmetrical in both eyes. Difference of more than 2 mm between the two eyes is considered significant. The simplest instrument to measure proptosis is Luedde's exophthalmometer However Hertel's exophthalmometer is the most commonly used instrumen Its advantage is that it measures the two eyes simultaneously.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: A,C,D- All these conditions cannot be measured by this instrument.

questions.text: A 8 yr old boy not able to see blackboard came for refractive correction. Spectacle prescription of -1D spherical and -2D cylindrical at 180 degrees was given. Type of astigmatism is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

With the rule -1D S, -2DC @ 180 degree As vertical meridian > horizontal meridian Hence, the type of astigmatism is with the rule. Step 1- -1D spherical would mean a power of -1D on vertical and horizontal axis. Step 2- -2D cylindrical at 180 degree mean , power of -2D at 90 degree(perpendicular to 180) So total power in vertical meridian will be = -1-2= -3D Total power in horizontal meridian will be = -1D Hence vertical meridian (-3D) is greater than horizontal meridian (-1D), it will be with the rule astigmatism.

Highyeild:

TYPES OF REGULAR ASTIGMATISM With-the-rule astigmatism (WTR) - In this type the two principal meridians are placed at right angles to one another but the vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal. Against-the-rule astigmatism (ATR) - It is an astigmatic condition in which the horizontal meridians is more curved than the vertical meridian . Oblique astigmatism - It is a type of regular astigmatism where the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical though these are at right angle to one another. Bioblique astigmatism - In this type of regular astigmatism the two principal meridians are not at right angle to each other, e.g. one may be at 30° and other at 100°.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: A- In against the rule astigmatism horizontal meridian is greater than the vertical meridian. OPTION: C- In simple astigmatism, one of the meridian focuses on the retina. The other meridian focuses either in front of the retina or behind the retina. OPTION: D- Mixed astigmatism refers to a condition wherein the light rays in one meridian are focused in front and in other meridian behind the retina . Thus, in one meridian eye is myopic and in another hypermetropic.

questions.text: A man with known history of diabetes has come to your clinic. His vision is 6/6. However, on retinal examination, he is classified to have severe NPDR. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Disc Neovascularization Neovascularization is characteristic of proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It is unlikely to be found in c/o non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Highyeild:

NON PROLIFERATIVE DIABETIC RETINOPATHY ETDRS study classification : On the basis of severity of the above findings, the NPDR has been further classified as under: Mild NPDR - At least one microaneurysm must be present. 2.Moderate NPDR - Microaneurysms/intraretinal haemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants. Early mild IRMA. Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present. Severe NPDR - Any one of the following (4-2-1 Rule): • Four quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal haemorrhages. Two quadrants of venous beading. • One quadrant of IRMA changes. Very severe NPDR - Any two of the following (4-2-1 Rule) Four quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal haemorrhages. Two quadrants of venous beading. One quadrant of IRMA changes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: A- Retinal microvascular abnormalities are feature of non-proliferative diabetic Retinopathy. OPTION: B- Venous beading is also seen in non-proliferative diabetic Retinopathy. OPTION: D- Retinal Hemorrhage is also a feature of non-proliferative diabetic Retinopathy.

questions.text: Identify the filter, the dye and the condition shown below :

options.label: B
options.text: Cobalt blue – Fluorescein dye – Corneal ulcer

options.label: C
options.text: Cobalt blue – Lissamine green dye – Corneal opacity

options.label: D
options.text: Cobalt green – Rose Bengal dye – Interstitial keratitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Cobalt blue – Fluorescein dye – Corneal ulcer
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cobalt blue – Fluorescein dye – Corneal ulcer The given image is most likely of corneal ulcer visualized with fluorescein green dye under cobalt blue filter. Corneal ulcers are detected with the help of fluorescein sodium dye and cobalt blue filter. Epithelial defects in corneal ulcers appear brilliant green after getting stained with fluorescein and appear opaque green with a cobalt blue filter.

Highyeild:

DYES USED IN OPHTHALMOLOGY FLUORESCEIN SODIUM - Used for Corneal staining to detect abrasion and ulcer Epithelial defect of cornea stain bright green in white light and opaque green with cobalt blue light FLUOREXONE Fluorexone does not stain most of the soft contact lenses and is thus used in eyes when fluorescein is contraindicated to avoid staining of soft contact lenses. Evaluation of corneal integrity of patients wearing hydrogel contact lenses. Tear film BUT Applanation tonometry without removing soft contact lens. INDOCYANINE GREEN ICG Fundus angiography , TCG-enhanced anterior capsulorrhexis . ICG-enhanced posterior capsulorrhexis. ROSE BENGAL AND LISSAMINE GREEN These dyes stain the devitalized, (degenerated and dead cells of conjunctiva and cornea and also the mucous fibrils. These are particularly useful in ocular surface disorders particularly dry eyes, i.e. keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS). TRYPAN BLUE Trypan blue is a commonly used dye to enhance the visualization of the anterior lens capsule before performing anterior capsulotomy/capsulorrhexis during cataract surgery. VERTEPORFIN It is used in photodynamic therapy (PDT) for wet age-related macular degeneration in patients with classic Sub foveal choroidal neovascularization (CNVM).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - All other options combination is wrong.

questions.text: A 21yr old boxer comes for permanent correction of refractive error. Which of the following should be avoided?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RK K i.e., radial keratotomy should be avoided in sports persons . As it may cause astigmatism due to radial incision & thinning of the cornea leading to corneal perforation at the site of incision.

Highyeild:

RADIAL KERATOTOMY Radial keratotomy (RK) refers to making deep (90% of corneal thickness) radial incisions in the peripheral part of cornea leaving the central 4 mm optical zone. These incisions on healing; flatten the central cornea thereby reducing its refractive power. This procedure gives good correction in low to moderate myopia (2 to 6 D). However, because of its disadvantages and advent of safe techniques ( LASIK and PRK ) RK is not recommended presently. DISADVANTAGES OF RK Cornea is weakened, so chances of globe rupture following trauma are more after RK than after PRK. This point is particularly important for patients who are at high risk of blunt trauma, e.g. sports persons, athletes and military personnel. Rarely, uneven healing may lead to irregular astigmatism. Patients may feel glare at night.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: B- PRK is photorefractive keratectomy which corrects myopia by using excimer laser. It is safer than RK and it can correct upto -6D of myopia. OPTION: C- LASIK is Laser assisted in situ keratomileusis and it is the most commonly done surgery for myopia. It is much safer and in it excimer laser reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp microkeratome. OPTION: D- SMILE is small incision lenticule extraction and in it a lenticule of corneal stroma is extracted using femtosecond laser. It can correct myopia upto 10D.

questions.text: This patient who is a known case of multiple sclerosis developed diplopia 2 weeks ago which was worse on looking to the right. Convergence is normal. Where is the lesion most likely to be located?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left MLF Contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation , which then sends efferents to the ipsilateral CN VI nucleus at the level of the facial colliculus in the dorsal pons. Subsequently, the CN VI nucleus projects to the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle (abducts the eye) and contralateral medial rectus subnucleus of CN III (adducts the eye) via the MLF. Unilateral MLF lesions can occur with lacunar stroke in the pontine artery distribution, although bilateral lesions are classically seen in multiple sclerosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. is incorrect because MLF lesions cause contralateral gaze palsy e Right MLF lesion causes Left gaze palsy, not right gaze palsy. Option: B: is incorrect because convergence remains normal Option: D. is incorrect because PPRF lesions cause ipsilateral gaze palsy i.e Left PPRF lesion causes Left gaze palsy, but the gaze palsy in the question is right gaze palsy.

Extraedge:

This patient has internuclear ophthalmoplegia, a disorder of conjugate horizontal gaze resulting from damage to the heavily-myelinated fibers of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). The MLF is a paired neural tract that mediates communication between CN III (oculomotor) and CN VI (abducens) nuclei , allowing for coordinated horizontal eye movements.
